spec.title: CSS Values and Units Module Level 5

values.name: numeric-only
values.prose: An <intrinsic-size-keyword> cannot be interpolated.

values.name: allow-keywords
values.prose: Two values can be interpolated if one of them is an <intrinsic-size-keyword> and the other is a <length-percentage>. This is done by treating the <intrinsic-size-keyword> keyword as though it is calc-size(keyword, size) and applying the rules in § 10.3 Interpolating calc-size(). In other cases, an <intrinsic-size-keyword> still cannot be interpolated.

values.name: <request-url-modifier>
values.prose: <request-url-modifier>s are <url-modifier>s that affect the <url>’s resource request by applying associated URL request modifier steps. See CSS Values 4 § 4.5.4 URL Processing Model.

values.name: crossorigin()
values.prose: <crossorigin-modifier> = crossorigin(anonymous | use-credentials)

values.name: anonymous
values.prose: <crossorigin-modifier> = crossorigin(anonymous | use-credentials)

values.name: use-credentials
values.prose: <crossorigin-modifier> = crossorigin(anonymous | use-credentials)

values.name: integrity()
values.prose: <integrity-modifier> = integrity(<string>)

values.name: <referrerpolicy-modifier>
values.value: referrerpolicy(no-referrer | no-referrer-when-downgrade | same-origin | origin | strict-origin | origin-when-cross-origin | strict-origin-when-cross-origin | unsafe-url)

values.name: referrerpolicy()
values.prose: <referrerpolicy-modifier> = referrerpolicy(no-referrer | no-referrer-when-downgrade | same-origin | origin | strict-origin | origin-when-cross-origin | strict-origin-when-cross-origin | unsafe-url)

values.name: no-referrer
values.prose: <referrerpolicy-modifier> = referrerpolicy(no-referrer | no-referrer-when-downgrade | same-origin | origin | strict-origin | origin-when-cross-origin | strict-origin-when-cross-origin | unsafe-url)

values.name: no-referrer-when-downgrade
values.prose: <referrerpolicy-modifier> = referrerpolicy(no-referrer | no-referrer-when-downgrade | same-origin | origin | strict-origin | origin-when-cross-origin | strict-origin-when-cross-origin | unsafe-url)

values.name: same-origin
values.prose: <referrerpolicy-modifier> = referrerpolicy(no-referrer | no-referrer-when-downgrade | same-origin | origin | strict-origin | origin-when-cross-origin | strict-origin-when-cross-origin | unsafe-url)

values.name: origin
values.prose: <referrerpolicy-modifier> = referrerpolicy(no-referrer | no-referrer-when-downgrade | same-origin | origin | strict-origin | origin-when-cross-origin | strict-origin-when-cross-origin | unsafe-url)

values.name: strict-origin
values.prose: <referrerpolicy-modifier> = referrerpolicy(no-referrer | no-referrer-when-downgrade | same-origin | origin | strict-origin | origin-when-cross-origin | strict-origin-when-cross-origin | unsafe-url)

values.name: origin-when-cross-origin
values.prose: <referrerpolicy-modifier> = referrerpolicy(no-referrer | no-referrer-when-downgrade | same-origin | origin | strict-origin | origin-when-cross-origin | strict-origin-when-cross-origin | unsafe-url)

values.name: strict-origin-when-cross-origin
values.prose: <referrerpolicy-modifier> = referrerpolicy(no-referrer | no-referrer-when-downgrade | same-origin | origin | strict-origin | origin-when-cross-origin | strict-origin-when-cross-origin | unsafe-url)

values.name: unsafe-url
values.prose: <referrerpolicy-modifier> = referrerpolicy(no-referrer | no-referrer-when-downgrade | same-origin | origin | strict-origin | origin-when-cross-origin | strict-origin-when-cross-origin | unsafe-url)

values.name: <position>
values.prose: The <position> value specifies the position of an alignment subject (e.g. a background image) inside an alignment container (e.g. its background positioning area) as a pair of offsets between the specified edges (defaulting to the left and top). Its syntax is:

values.name: <length-percentage>
values.prose: A <length-percentage> value specifies the size of the offset between the specified edges of the alignment subject and alignment container. For example, for background-position: 2cm 1cm, the top left corner of the background image is placed 2cm to the right and 1cm below the top left corner of the background positioning area. A <percentage> for the horizontal offset is relative to (width of alignment container - width of alignment subject). A <percentage> for the vertical offset is relative to (height of alignment container - height of alignment subject). For example, with a value pair of 0% 0%, the upper left corner of the alignment subject is aligned with the upper left corner of the alignment container A value pair of 100% 100% places the lower right corner of the alignment subject in the lower right corner of the alignment container. With a value pair of 75% 50%, the point 75% across and 50% down the alignment subject is to be placed at the point 75% across and 50% down the alignment container. Diagram of the meaning of background-position: 75% 50%.

values.name: top
values.prose: Offsets the top/left/right/bottom edges (respectively) of the alignment subject and alignment container by the specified amount (defaulting to 0%) in the corresponding axis.

values.name: right
values.prose: Offsets the top/left/right/bottom edges (respectively) of the alignment subject and alignment container by the specified amount (defaulting to 0%) in the corresponding axis.

values.name: bottom
values.prose: Offsets the top/left/right/bottom edges (respectively) of the alignment subject and alignment container by the specified amount (defaulting to 0%) in the corresponding axis.

values.name: left
values.prose: Offsets the top/left/right/bottom edges (respectively) of the alignment subject and alignment container by the specified amount (defaulting to 0%) in the corresponding axis.

values.name: y-start
values.prose: Computes the same as the physical edge keyword corresponding to the start/end side in the [=y-axis|y/x axis.

values.name: y-end
values.prose: Computes the same as the physical edge keyword corresponding to the start/end side in the [=y-axis|y/x axis.

values.name: x-start
values.prose: Computes the same as the physical edge keyword corresponding to the start/end side in the [=y-axis|y/x axis.

values.name: x-end
values.prose: Computes the same as the physical edge keyword corresponding to the start/end side in the [=y-axis|y/x axis.

values.name: block-start
values.prose: Computes the same as the physical edge keyword corresponding to the start/end side in the block/inline axis.

values.name: block-end
values.prose: Computes the same as the physical edge keyword corresponding to the start/end side in the block/inline axis.

values.name: inline-start
values.prose: Computes the same as the physical edge keyword corresponding to the start/end side in the block/inline axis.

values.name: inline-end
values.prose: Computes the same as the physical edge keyword corresponding to the start/end side in the block/inline axis.

values.name: center
values.prose: Computes to a 50% offset in the corresponding axis.

values.name: <position-one>
values.value: [ left | center | right | top | bottom | x-start | x-end | y-start | y-end | block-start | block-end | inline-start | inline-end | <length-percentage> ]

values.name: <position-two>
values.value: [ [ left | center | right | x-start | x-end ] && [ top | center | bottom | y-start | y-end ] | [ left | center | right | x-start | x-end | <length-percentage> ] [ top | center | bottom | y-start | y-end | <length-percentage> ] | [ block-start | center | block-end ] && [ inline-start | center | inline-end ] | [ start | center | end ]{2} ]

values.name: <position-four>
values.value: [ [ [ left | right | x-start | x-end ] <length-percentage> ] && [ [ top | bottom | y-start | y-end ] <length-percentage> ] | [ [ block-start | block-end ] <length-percentage> ] && [ [ inline-start | inline-end ] <length-percentage> ] | [ [ start | end ] <length-percentage> ]{2} ]

values.name: progress()
values.prose: The progress() functional notation returns a <number> value representing the position of one calculation (the progress value) between two other calculations (the progress start value and progress end value). The argument calculations can resolve to any <number>, <dimension>, or <percentage>, but must have a consistent type or else the function is invalid. The result will be a <number>, made consistent with the consistent type of the arguments.

values.name: media-progress()
values.prose: Similar to the progress() notation, the media-progress() functional notation returns a <number> value representing current value of the specified media query [MEDIAQUERIES-4] as a progress value between two explicit values of the media query (as the progress start value and progress end value).

values.name: container-progress()
values.prose: The container-progress() functional notation is identical to the media-progress() functional notation, except that it accepts container features [CSS-CONTAIN-3] in place of media features.

values.name: <progress>
values.prose: The <progress> value type represents the mix progress value in a mix notation, and ultimately resolves to a percentage. It can, however, draw that percentage value from sources such as media queries and animation timelines, and can also convert it through an easing function before using it for interpolation.

values.name: <percentage-token>
values.prose: Computes to the equivalent <number>: 0% becomes 0, 100% becomes 1, etc.

values.name: <number>
values.prose: Represents the mix progress value.

values.name: <'animation-timeline'>
values.prose: Represents the mix progress value as the progress of the specified animation timeline. The values none and auto, however, are invalid. [CSS-ANIMATIONS-2] [WEB-ANIMATIONS-2]

values.name: <easing-function>
values.prose: Converts the specified input mix progress value into an output mix progress value using the specified easing function. [CSS-EASING-1]

values.name: calc-mix()
values.prose: The calc-mix() mix notation represents an interpolated numeric or dimensional value. Like calc(), it is a math function, with the following syntactic form:

values.name: transform-mix()
values.prose: The transform-mix() mix notation represents an interpolated <transform-list>, with the following syntactic form:

values.name: mix()
values.prose: Interpolation of any two property values can be represented by the mix() mix notation, which supports two alternative syntax patterns:

values.name: first-valid()
values.prose: The first-valid() functional notation inlines the fallback behavior intrinsic to parsing declarations. Unlike most notations, it can accept any valid or invalid syntax in its arguments, and represents the first value among its arguments that is supported (parsed as valid) by the UA as the whole value of the property it’s used in.

values.name: toggle()
values.prose: The toggle() expression allows descendant elements to cycle over a list of values instead of inheriting the same value.

values.name: attr()
values.prose: The attr() function substitutes the value of an attribute on an element into a property, similar to how the var() function substitutes a custom property value into a function.

values.name: string
values.prose: The substitution value is a CSS string, whose value is the literal value of the attribute. (No CSS parsing or "cleanup" of the value is performed.) No value triggers fallback.

values.name: ident
values.prose: The substitution value is a CSS <custom-ident>, whose value is the literal value of the attribute, with leading and trailing ASCII whitespace stripped. (No CSS parsing of the value is performed.) If the attribute value, after trimming, is the empty string, there is instead no substitution value. If the <custom-ident>’s value is a CSS-wide keyword or default, there is instead no substitution value.

values.name: color
values.prose: Parse a component value from the attribute’s value. If the result is a <hex-color> or a named color ident, the substitution value is that result as a <color>. Otherwise there is no substitution value.

values.name: number
values.prose: Parse a component value from the attribute’s value. If the result is a <number-token>, the result is the substitution value. Otherwise, there is no substitution value.

values.name: percentage
values.prose: Parse a component value from the attribute’s value. If the result is a <percentage-token>, the result is the substitution value. Otherwise, there is no substitution value.

values.name: length
values.prose: Parse a component value from the attribute’s value. If the result is a <dimension-token> whose unit matches the given type, the result is the substitution value. Otherwise, there is no substitution value.

values.name: angle
values.prose: Parse a component value from the attribute’s value. If the result is a <dimension-token> whose unit matches the given type, the result is the substitution value. Otherwise, there is no substitution value.

values.name: time
values.prose: Parse a component value from the attribute’s value. If the result is a <dimension-token> whose unit matches the given type, the result is the substitution value. Otherwise, there is no substitution value.

values.name: frequency
values.prose: Parse a component value from the attribute’s value. If the result is a <dimension-token> whose unit matches the given type, the result is the substitution value. Otherwise, there is no substitution value.

values.name: flex
values.prose: Parse a component value from the attribute’s value. If the result is a <dimension-token> whose unit matches the given type, the result is the substitution value. Otherwise, there is no substitution value.

values.name: <dimension-unit>
values.prose: Parse a component value from the attribute’s value. If the result is a <number-token>, the substitution value is a dimension with the result’s value, and the given unit. Otherwise, there is no substitution value.

values.name: <attr-type>
values.value: string | ident | color | number | percentage | length | angle | time | frequency | flex | <dimension-unit>

values.name: <dimension-unit>
values.prose: The <dimension-unit> production matches a literal "%" character (that is, a <delim-token> with a value of "%") or an ident whose value is any of the CSS units for <length>, <angle>, <time>, <frequency>, or <flex> values (such as px or ms).

values.name: random()
values.prose: The random() function is a math function that represents a random value between a minimum and maximum value, drawn from a uniform distribution, optionally limiting the possible values to a step between those limits:

values.name: random-item()
values.prose: The random-item() function resolves to a random item from among its list of items.

values.name: sibling-count()
values.prose: The sibling-count() functional notation represents, as an <integer>, the total number of child elements in the parent of the element on which the notation is used.

values.name: sibling-index()
values.prose: The sibling-index() functional notation represents, as an <integer>, the index of the element on which the notation is used among the children of its parent. Like :nth-child(), sibling-index() is 1-indexed.

values.name: size
values.prose: Within the calc-size calculation, if the calc-size basis is not any, the keyword size is allowed. This keyword is a <length>, and resolves at used value time.

values.name: any
values.prose: (If the calc-size basis is any, the calc-size() is a definite length, equal to its calc-size calculation.)

values.name: <intrinsic-size-keyword>
values.prose: The <intrinsic-size-keyword> production matches any intrinsic size keywords allowed in the context. For example, in width, it matches auto, min-content, stretch, etc.

warnings.name: progress-function()
warnings.value: progress-function( progress value from start value to end value )
